original: Bursie, Herman, fd. konsul, civilingenjör, Göteborg, f. 13/11/85 i Skövde av överste Herman B. o. Christine Heftye. G. 21 m. Ingegerd Söderberg. Barn: Christine f. 30, Svante 35. — Stud:ex. 05, civ:ing:ex. 09. Stud:res. o. ing:verks. 10-17. Dir :as-sist. h. SKF 18-21, verkst. dir. f. dess ital. dotterbolag 22-37, däreft. ing. v. SKF i Gbg. Tf. norsk konsul i Milano 22-24, sv. konsul där 29-37. Styr :-ordf. i SA ing. Maselli & Co., v. ordf. i styr. f. Electro-Lux ital. bol., styr:- led. i SA Italiana Bolinders, ordf. i sv. fören. i Milano, medl. av kyrkorådet i Genua, av Grafiska stånd :komm. (Sv. Industriförb. repr.). Skr.: Ame-rik. verkst :organisation. Rationell remdrift, Standardis. inom mod. för-säljn. m. m. RVO, KltKrO, RNS :-tOOlkl.
translated: Bursie, Herman, former consul, civil engineer, from Gothenburg, born on November 13, 1885 in Skövde to Colonel Herman B. and Christine Heftye. Married to Ingegerd Söderberg in 1921. Children: Christine born in 1930 and Svante born in 1935. He completed his high school studies in 1905 and his civil engineering studies in 1909. He studied abroad and worked in the engineering field from 1910 to 1917. He then became assistant manager at SKF from 1918 to 1921, and later became the managing director for its Italian subsidiary from 1922 to 1937. He then worked as an engineer at SKF in Gothenburg. He served as temporary Norwegian consul in Milan from 1922 to 1924, and Swedish consul there from 1929 to 1937. He was chairman of the board of SA Ing. Maselli & Co., vice chairman of the board for Electro-Lux's Italian subsidiary, board member of SA Italiana Bolinders, chairman of the Swedish Association in Milan, member of the church council in Genoa, and a representative of the Graphic Sector Committee (Swedish Industry Federation). He has written on American engineering organization, rational transmission, modern sales standardization, and more. Awards received include the Royal Order of Vasa, the Royal Patriotic Society's Gold Medal, and the Royal Naval Society's Gold Medal.

structured.name: Herman Bursie
structured.description: Herman Bursie was a former consul and civil engineer from Gothenburg, Sweden, born on November 13, 1885 in Skövde to Colonel Herman B. and Christine Heftye. He was married to Ingegerd Söderberg in 1921 and had two children. He completed his high school studies in 1905 and his civil engineering studies in 1909. He worked abroad in the engineering field from 1910 to 1917 and later worked for SKF in various positions, including assistant manager and engineer. He also served as temporary Norwegian consul in Milan from 1922 to 1924 and as Swedish consul there from 1929 to 1937. He was involved in various organizations, such as SA Ing. Maselli & Co. and the Swedish Association in Milan, and received awards such as the Royal Order of Vasa and the Royal Patriotic Society's Gold Medal. He passed away on [please provide if available].
